newsitem.title: UK: Kingfisher up 6.7 pct, leads retail rally. [CORRECTED 13:25 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Kingfisher up 6.7 pct, leads retail rally. [CORRECTED 13:25 GMT]

text.p: Kingfisher Plc shares rocketed 6.7 percent on Thursday, leading a rally in retail stocks after the Bank of England raised rates by just a quarter percentage point after a meeting of its monetary policy committee.

Extending early gains on the back of positive comment on Wednesday's figures from rival Dixons Group Plc, Kingfisher shares were up 46-1/2p at 739 (corrects price from 439) by 1134 GMT and other leading UK retailers also rose sharply.

With the sector also boosted by an upbeat trading statement from Storehouse Plc, there was renewed interest across the board in a sector that has underperformed the rest of the UK equity market in recent months.
"There's a lot of relief around in the retail sector," said one head of equity trading. "They were given a real hammering and now everyone is just very happy."

With prices squeezed higher by a shortage of stock among market-makers after recent gains, blue chip retailer Marks & Spencer Plc was up 24p at 558-1/2 and Great Universal Stores Plc was up 13p at 627-1/2.
Catalogue retailer Argos Plc was up 19-1/2p at 585, drugstore chain Boots Co Plc gained 37p to 819 and Storehouse leapt 13p to 201.
Dixons Group Plc was up 27-1/2p at 564.

Earlier the Bank of England said it raised its base lending rate by a quarter point to 6.75 percent, in line with expectations and dousing fears of a possible half-point increase that could have dented consumer confidence.
"The market will like this a damn sight more than 50 basis points, maybe there will be some relief for... retailers," said Andy Hartwill, strategist at SocGen.
